Case Study:

 A bold reimagining of access to non-emergency public services

Overview

HelpNow is imagined as an alternative to 911 for people experiencing homelessness and food shortage issues. It allows individuals to locate assistance in Charlotte, NC. From homeless shelters and soup kitchens to pet care and healthcare, HelpNow can be used to search, find, and navigate countless resources in the city.

This is a graduate school project for the class Human-Centered Design. The app focuses on achieving a stellar UI and seamless user experience.

Roles
User Research, UX Design, UI Design
Time
12 Weeks

Ideation

“Apps for homeless people” might sound a bit weird. But cheap smartphones, outreach programs, and youth homelessness mean that many people have a phone but no home. (As of 2011, almost two thirds of homeless youth owned a cell phone.) And in several cities, they can use mobile apps to find food, shelter, and other resources.

A running theme in the news coverage of apps for Social Welfare is that they’re underused, and our preliminary research showed that it is because of poor User Experience. (Many apps never even get past the institutional resistance and regulation.) Instead, people keep calling already overloaded city services, or even the police. So considering all the factors, the overall objective of our application is to help homeless, displaced, and in-need individuals find shelter and food services efficiently and effectively.

Research

After deciding on our design topic, our first step was to start doing some research.

  • We interviewed stakeholders on all sides of the issue, from homeless individuals to shelter managers and policy shapers in oversight organizations.
  • We also conducted a literature review of peer reviewed academic journals, newspaper articles, radio broadcast transcripts, and articles found online in order to gain background knowledge on issues surrounding homelessness, technology use, and shelter finding experiences.
  • We rounded out the research with a survey of 22 homeless individuals who we encountered on the streets and in homeless shelters.

Shelter Administrators : Are frustrated with the manual process of matching people with shelters

  • Right now “you can only call in one day of the week. The calling hours might open at 9 am and by 10 all the appointments for that week are booked.”
  • The current wait time for the 800+ families in the family housing connection queue is “upwards of a few months.”

There is a lack of transparency for client information resulting in possible duplication of services across agencies

  • Poor communication between agencies is limiting collaboration.
  • Interviewees reported that the current system has “has removed our ability to share information and collaborate with each other” between agencies.
  • Most shelter organizations use their own systems to track client intake and information.

Homeless/clients:

  • Do not have a lot of autonomy or control over the housing placement process.
  • Lack of knowledge about all the available services in the city.
  • Are frustrated with the current system’s slow intake and processing times.

A running theme in the news coverage of apps for Social Welfare is that they’re underused, and our preliminary research showed that it is because of poor User Experience. (Many apps never even get past the institutional resistance and regulation.) Instead, people keep calling already overloaded city services, or even the police. So considering all the factors, the overall objective of our application is to help homeless, displaced, and in-need individuals find shelter and food services efficiently and effectively.

Design Goals

Our App focuses on the features intended for our primary user base, people in need of food and/or shelter. The design goals for the prototype include:

  • Helping people in need efficiently find food and shelter services information.
  • Developing a simple and easy-to-use interface that allows users to discover what’s available in their area, and search/filter based on their needs.
  • Providing real-time updates and information on available shelters and food resources (e.g. what is currently open).

Eventually, we hope a fully-functional version of our application would also be used by employees of relevant service organizations, such as soup kitchens and homeless shelters. Future design goals for our application include:

  • Giving shelters and food banks a medium to disseminate information about their services, updates, and announcements.
  • Developing a simple interface so organizations can easily provide status information and updates in real-time.

Design Description & Design Rationale

Our target user demographic greatly influenced our decision to design our prototype as a public, interactive, touch-screen display. Through our initial needfinding studies, we found that almost all our participants who were temporarily displaced or homeless had access to technology and internet (through personal, shared, or public devices). However, we realized this is only a small sample of our target user base. For many others, access to technology and/or the internet is a luxury they cannot afford.

We chose to test our high fidelity prototype in Charlotte, North Carolina. Using the city as the test market for the prototype, we found that many food banks and shelters are located in and around the center-city, uptown neighborhoods. Similarly in other larger cities, these resources and services are often clustered in metropolitan areas. Higher homeless populations are correlated in these densely-population urban areas: in North Carolina, the city of Charlotte accounts for most of the state’s homelessness by population numbers and percentage of general population (source: National Alliance to End Homelessness). Ideally, our public display would be installed in a highly-populated metro area, where: 1: it is easily accessible to large populations of displaced and homeless individuals, and 2: it is in close proximity to numerous shelter and food services. Keeping this in mind, additional design rationale breaks down as follows:

  • Touch screens are fairly simple to operate.
  • More accessible and more useful: providing a public display means users without personal/shared technology devices can still access our application.
  • Information and updates can be set to roll and displayed automatically, so everyone using our application will simultaneously get real-time statuses and information.
  • We initially considered three prototypes: website, kiosk, and public display. Of the three, the public display had the best visibility, usefulness, discoverability, and ease of use.

Personas & Story Boards

With the goal feature in mind, we needed to understand how users could approach this feature. How would they interact differently on a desktop compared to a mobile device? We developed and used a primary persona: Jake, and two secondary personas as tools for this process. A main takeaway from this was the minimum required pages we would need for our first prototype.

here

Information & System Architecture

Information architecture (IA) is all about organization of information in a clear and logical way. Such organization follows a clear purpose — helping users navigate complex sets of information. The challenge when building IA is in understanding how your app or website actually works from the user’s perspective, and how to organize that information into a readable, legible format. There are two major requirements for actually constructing IA: organizing it through a visual hierarchy (that is, a hierarchy of features, functions, and behavior) and creating a legend for displaying different types of features, interactions, and flows. In other words, the most important factors to building your IA are where individual components of the architecture are placed (hierarchically), and how they’re labeled and displayed. We all know how important it is to produce content that users will find valuable, but what’s equally important is to make that content findable. Time is the most precious resource people have. We live in a world where people expect to find a solution to their problems with the least amount of effort. When the process of finding information is too complicated or too slow, there’s a risk that people will simply abandon it.

High Fidelity Prototypes

Once we finished our third round of user tests, I moved on to skinning the prototype to give it a clean visual user interface. I made my choices for color pallet, flat buttons, and visual icons based on Patelco’s current branding styles. I belived that keeping this style when working for a client is highly important: my job in redesign is not to rebrand my client, only to better communicate their website for their users to understand.

here

here

Evaluation Methodology

Evaluating rapid prototypes should employ quick and light-weight feedback methods, reflecting the low risk stage and stakes at this stage of the process, and focus primarily on getting rapid feedback from would-be users or participants about a new idea. Based on the aforementioned principles, we tried to get as much Heuristic evaluation done while designing the prototype and decided to conduct a user study with the final design, using questionnaires and interviews.

We had to take into account the fact that usability is not intrinsically objective in nature but is rather closely intertwined with an evaluator’s personal interpretation of the artefact and his or her interaction with it. We conducted the user studies by first giving the participant background information about our motivation for this project. Next, we asked them to complete pre-defined tasks. Then, we gave them a paper (or have them enter it on a computer) and had them answer the survey questions. At the end of the evaluation, we asked the participants a few open-ended questions out loud and noted their answers.

Evaluation Goals

  • Evaluate the visibility and discoverability of the prototype.
  • Evaluate the ease of use of the prototype.
  • Evaluate the effectiveness of the prototype.

Measurements & Metrics

  • Usability (Success rate (whether users can perform the task at all), the time a task requires, the error rate, and users' subjective satisfaction.)
  • How discoverable & visible the prototype is.
  • How easy it is for a user to navigate the UI.
  • How helpful the participants believe our prototype will be in a needy situation.

Evaluation Results

In the survey, we had a total of 12 participants (8 males and 4 females). The result to each question was analyzed, and we include comments made by participants in the free response questions asked.

We further analyzed the results of our participants using One-way Analysis of Variance (ANOVA) to determine whether there were any statistically significant differences between the female participants (Group 1) and the male participants (Group 2). Analysis of Variance Results: F-statistic value = 0.08424 P-value = 0.77249

Modifications based on Evaluation Results

While conducting the user studies, we uncovered a few modifications to make on the prototype and future work on the finished product. One minor improvement is increasing the font size of the search results. Some participants had trouble reading it, and they mentioned that it may be more difficult to read on a large screen if someone was far away but still wanted to see what was going on. Participants also suggested that we provide better labeling of the pages to make the purpose of the application a little more clear. For instance, one participant was confused by the wording “available now” on the main search screen next to each organization (food bank or shelter). They thought it would be more clear to reword it to “open now.” They also said, “It is not very obvious what this display is all about. At first glance it just looks like a Google map search. Maybe a title or logo that lets people know that this is a display for people needing shelter or food? Otherwise homeless people walking right by it might not ever use it if they don’t know what it is.” This same participant suggested that the number of markers on the map should be consistent with the number of results on the side panel. This would be implemented as future work, since our prototype is not yet fully functional.

Many participants reported that they were unable to find the daily hours, as the days and times were not specified. They said they would prefer an expanded list, where each day is listed individually with its hours next to it. This would be another minor modification to make in our prototype, which would enhance discoverability.

Regarding the big screen implementation, a few participants reported that they would not feel comfortable using this on the big screen, due to privacy concerns. They suggested that there should also be a mobile app and/or website version of the application. This would provide more privacy to users if they did not feel comfortable using it publicly. This would also make it more convenient for those who may not live or currently be near one of the big screens (so they could access it anywhere).
